item.description: TL;DR: I wanted to write more about building my Easy-Blog Oven. I mainly glued together things I already knew, but I think I learned some things and had some surprises anyway.

item.title: Firefox Test Pilot: The Flattening
item.description: TL;DR: Firefox Test Pilot is becoming a statically-generated site from content in flat files. We're moving away from Django and PostgreSQL, and it's been a bit of a journey.

item.title: Continual Blogployment

item.title: Adding Android to a multi-platform React app
The web is awesome
item.description: TL;DR: The open web is a beautiful thing that empowers makers while offering users leverage. There's nothing else like it. It's constantly improving. It's up to you what you do with it.

item.title: Experimenting with a multi-platform app using React
item.description: TL;DR: I built a toy app using React for web and native to get a feel for whether this hybrid approach is worth using. I think the answer is "yes" - but mainly for apps whose business logic & data models are more complex than their views.

item.title: The Verge's web sucks
item.description: TL;DR: Did you know that The Verge delivers you to around 20 companies for advertising & tracking purposes? I didn't. That might foul up your web experience a little bit. Maybe we should try something different.

item.title: Static blog generation with Gulp and S3
item.description: I've long agreed that many sites, like blogs, are better baked than fried. It makes for web hosting that's cheaper to run and simpler to maintain. I've also often thought that using a database can be an anti-pattern for managing content. But, what I've also found is that baked sites often yield a poor writing environment. That said, I think I'm going to give it another try, because I think I might have found a new approach that works for me.

item.title: tootr: microblogging app, hosting not included
item.description: In my last two posts, I wrote about how I’ve been thinking about building yet another microblogging tool and how I think it might be interesting to separate web publishing apps from web hosting. Well, I started tinkering, and I’ve got a rough prototype working.
